title-group.article-title: Experimental study of a cavitation heat generator

abstract.p: Recent research has investigated the use of ultrasonic or hydrodynamic cavitation for chemical reactors, water treatment equipment, and heat generators. In this article, a new cavitation heat generator is introduced. The proposed system utilizes an electric motor to rotate the generator, and various experiments are performed by changing the flow conditions such as inlet pressure and rotating velocity to evaluate the performance of it. In addition, the amount of heat generation is measured and the thermal efficiency is evaluated. The result is a highly efficient heat generator that can reach 90% thermal efficiency.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cavitation can cause erosion, vibration, and noise, often inhibiting the performance of the machinery, and is generally considered a phenomenon that engineers should avoid. Yet, various research involving cavitation for use in heat generators, water treatment equipment, and chemical reactors, for example, has been conducted recently.1,2 Among the machinery employing cavitation, those using hydrodynamic cavitation performed better than those using acoustic cavitation. Hydrodynamic cavitation is more efficient and applicable on a large scale than acoustic cavitation.1 For instance, vortex heat generators and cavitation heat generators are both examples of generators that use hydrodynamic cavitation.3,4 Additionally, according to the documents written by the manufacturers of cavitation heat generators, the thermal efficiency of cavitation heat generators is purportedly higher than any other heating machine. However, Little5 reported that the efficiency was found to be around 80% after a performance test for one of these cavitation heat generator models. In a different study, Zaporozhets et al.3 produced a device to generate cavitation bubbles, and the results of their experiment suggested that the amount of heat generation was 3.38 times more than the input electrical energy. Yet, their experimental method and thermal efficiency formula were not described in detail and the resultant experimental data were not thoroughly presented in the paper, making it difficult to believe that the thermal efficiency exceeded 100% because of thermal conservation.

Consequently, the current status of research in the field prompted a systematic study of a cavitation heat generator consisting of a newly designed front cover, rotor disc, and rear cover. Experiments were performed to measure the amount of heat generation, and the thermal efficiency was evaluated by changing the flow conditions, including the inlet pressure and the rotational velocity of the rotor. A 15 kW class electrical motor was used for these experimental studies. The results showed that the amount of heat generation was closely related to the flow conditions; e.g. a higher inlet pressure and a faster rotor rotational velocity increased the thermal efficiency until the maximum thermal efficiency of 90% was reached. Without considering the loss from the electrical motor, the thermal efficiency of this cavitation heat generator is higher than any other electric heating machine.

sec.title: Design of the cavitation heat generator
sec.p: Cavitation in liquid-handling machinery produces large amounts of energy that can cause the equipment to corrode and break. The mechanism of cavitation generally consists of three steps: First, nucleation of the bubble is created when the local pressure is lower than the saturated vapor pressure. Second, a cavitation bubble is enlarged until it reaches its maximum size. Finally, the bubble collapses when it is moved to a place where the local pressure exceeds the saturated vapor pressure. This collapsing bubble can reach temperatures of several thousands of kelvin. In fact, Didenko et al.6 measured the temperature of collapsing bubbles using spectral analysis of the light emitted from the collapsed bubbles and reported a measured temperature of 4300 ± 200 K.

The cavitation heat generator in this study generated numerous cavitation bubbles by rotating a disc, called the rotor, in the range 2100–3600 r/min. When the rotor was activated, the local pressure fell below the saturated vapor pressure and then returned to its original level along the flow path. During this process, the heat generated by the collapsed bubbles was used to increase the liquid temperature.

A schematic of the developed cavitation heat generator is illustrated in Figure 1. While the rotating disc creates a vortex, cavitation occurs due to the decreased pressure that falls below the saturated vapor pressure. Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of a cavitation heat generator.

In general, cavitation can be easily generated by the flow of liquid around a dimple-shaped cone or a sharp edge. Considering this fact, numerous cone-shaped dimples, each about 10 mm in diameter, were made on the surfaces of the front cover, the rotor disc and the rear cover, as shown in Figure 1. Gaps between the front and rear covers were also adjusted to produce the maximum amount of heat, as determined via a parametric study. The diameters of the front and rear covers were both 292 mm, while the diameter of the rotor was 288 mm.

On the rotor, 35 dimples were arranged so that they were equally spaced and located 122.5 mm from the center. On the front and rear covers, 40 and 32 dimples, respectively, were also equally spaced and located 122.5 mm from the center. The number of dimples differed on each part in order to avoid resonance, since equal numbers of dimples drastically increase the levels of vibration and noise.

sec.title: Flow visualization
sec.p: In order to observe the effect of the dimples on generating cavitation, the front cover was constructed of a plate of transparent acrylic. Then, a high-speed CCD camera captured images of the flows near the dimples at 14,000 frames/s and rotational velocity 3600 r/min.

Although the cavitation cycle, at one millionth of a second, was too short to fully capture using a high-speed camera, the process of generating cavitation via dimples was validated by the images shown in Figure 2. Generally, the greater the number of dimples, the greater the cavitation that can be generated; however, as excessive dimples require a large flow rate that could overload the motor, the number of dimples must be optimized. Figure 2.
Pictures for flow visualization by a high-speed CCD camera.

sec.title: Experiments
sec.p:
A schematic diagram of the experimental apparatus is illustrated in Figure 3. The temperature sensors were PT100 ohm sensors with a ±0.25% full-scale accuracy. The temperature sensor on the inlet side was located 300 mm upstream from the inlet in order to avoid the influence of the inlet. The other sensor was installed 150 mm downstream from the outlet. The outlet position was selected to provide sufficient space for the flow to mix with the collapsed cavitation bubbles. Both the inlet and outlet pipes had diameters of 15 mm. Additionally, electric pressure transmitters were used which had a range 0–5 bar (absolute pressure) with ±0.5% full-scale accuracy. The pressure sensor on the inlet side was installed 150 mm from the inlet, while the other one was set up 300 mm from the outlet to prevent any interference from the temperature sensors. Note that all measured pressures represent the absolute pressures. Next, an electromagnetic flow meter, ranging between 0 and 6.4 m3/h with an accuracy of ±0.5% of the reading scale, was installed. In order to measure the electric power consumed by the motor, a Yokogawa-CW240 was used for the power meter. All the signals from the temperature and pressure sensors were collected and converted into digital signals by an NI (National Instruments) PCI-6229 board via a data acquisition device. The electric power was measured by the power meter and collected through the serial communication between a computer and the power meter. Then, the temperature, pressure, and electric power data were processed and saved on the computer using a LabVIEW program. A booster pump was used to control the inlet pressure. The inverter, model iG5A (LS industrial), was connected to the motor to investigate the influence of the rotational velocity, which was incrementally increased from 2100 to 3600 r/min, and the measured data were collected at each step. Figure 3.
Experimental apparatus for the performance test.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The heat generation rate can be calculated using equation (1) (1)Q=ρ·cp·q·(T2-T1)
The thermal efficiency can be calculated using equation (2) (2)η=QPm×100 where the thermal efficiency is defined as the percent ratio of the heat generation rate to the electric power input.
The cavitation number, which is one of cavitation indices, can be defined using following equation (3)σv=P1-Pvρ·V2×500
Note that cubic spline interpolation was used to obtain the temperature values that were not originally provided in the table of reference.7

The generation of heat as a function of the inlet pressure and the rotational velocity is presented in Figures 4 and 5, respectively. The heat generator did not work when either the rotational velocity was below 2700 r/min or the inlet pressure was less than 1.25 bar, meaning that no cavitation occurred under these conditions. As shown in Figures 4 and 5, the heat generation rate increased when either the rotational velocity or the inlet pressure increased. In addition, the heat generation rate was influenced more by the rotational velocity than by the inlet pressure, suggesting that the higher rotational velocity could generate more cavitation bubbles. Figure 4.
Heat generation versus inlet pressure.
Figure 5.
Heat generation versus rotational velocity.

The relation between the cavitation number and heat generation is shown in Figure 6, where a low cavitation number indicates that cavitation bubbles can be created easily. Hence, the heat generation rate also increased for low cavitation numbers. Likewise, if no cavitation bubbles were created, the heat generation rate was very low. Consequently, the results in Figure 6 suggest that cavitation may be the most significant factor in heat generation. In some cases, however, even though the cavitation number was low enough, turbulence seemed to hinder the creation of cavitation bubbles. Figure 6.
Heat generation versus cavitation number.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article introduced a heat generator that used cavitation bubbles and presented its thermal efficiency, which was verified experimentally. Numerous dimples on surfaces of the front cover, rotor disc, and rear cover generated ample cavitation bubbles, which were confirmed from the flow visualization.

The relation between the inlet flow conditions and the heat generation rate was investigated experimentally. A higher inlet pressure and faster rotational velocity was found to increase the heat generation rate. In addition, the experiments showed that a lower cavitation number generated more heat. A maximum thermal efficiency of 90% was obtained, which is a superior result compared to other electric heat generators, provided the inlet pressure and rotating velocity are sufficiently high.

Note that the cavitation heat generator investigated in this article can be connected to wind or hydraulic turbines without an electric motor, making it an ideal candidate for practical application. Nevertheless, additional research is needed to investigate the relation between the heat generation and the flow conditions, such as cavitation and turbulence, both experimentally and theoretically.
